frameDefinitions: An Agent is involved in an activity whose degree of success is dependent on a parameter of the action matching a particular set of values of a continuous variable or variables (e.g. quantity, location, time).

The adjectives and nouns in this frame are all based on the idea that mental properties may be attributed to a person (Protagonist) by a (usually implicit) Judge  on the basis of that person's Behavior, as broadly understood.
A particular piece of Information is evaluated for its accuracy.
A Process stops at a certain Time and Place.
This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
This Frame is concerned with evaluating an Evaluee as being suitable for a Purpose or a User, presupposing some choice that is being made about which Evaluee to use for the Purpose or User.
frameExamples: The Longview Rangefinder is <t>accurate</t> to within one foot per hundred yards .
It was <t>stupid</t> of me to do that.
Is your reputation at risk due to <t>incorrect</t> information?
Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
(1) We need to build more houses <t>suitable</t> for local residents.
listRoleDefinitions: The individual who tries to interact with the <fen>Target</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Means</fen> by which the <fen>Agent</fen> attempts to hit a <fen>Target_value</fen>.
How closely the expected or actual location that the <fen>Instrument</fen> interacts with corresponds to the <fen>Target_value</fen>.
The object manipulated by the <fen>Agent</fen> in order to interact with the <fen>Target</fen>.
Expected or actual deviation from the <fen>Target_value</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when something hits or misses.
The place where the <fen>Agent</fen> manages or fails to interact with the <fen>Target</fen>.

This is the person (or people) to whom a mental property is attributed. The role may be expressed as External Argument of a predicative use of the adjective, as a PP Complement, or as the head noun modified by an attributive use of the adjective:

The <fen>Behavior</fen> refers to any action, utterance, belief, or artifact thereof on the basis of which a mental property is attributed to the <fen>Protagonist</fen>. The meaning of the English word <ment>behavior</ment> should not be taken to constrain the identity of this frame element too much---conceptually, this frame element includes things that would not normally be described using the word <ment>behavior</ment>.  Note the following examples:

Some of the words in this frame have a slightly different use in that they evaluate someone only with respect to their mental performance in some particular domain or capacity.  We call this domain or capacity <t>Practice</t>. E.g., She is <t>astute</t> <fex name='Practice'>at math</fex>. Note that this does not mean she is considered to be astute in general for doing math. Rather, she is astute with respect to math, but may be dumb with respect to other things. These uses probably belong in a different frame with words such as <ment>skilled</ment>, but for the time being they are marked with the role Practice. General Grammatical Observations:  The adjectives in this frame may exhibit Extraposition of a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP, with an optional Protagonist expressed in an <ment>of</ment>-PP: It was <t>brilliant</t> (of you) <fex name='Prac'>to invite the clowns to the party</fex>.
The <fen>Information</fen> matches or does not match the facts of the world.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the agent who holds the correct/incorrect information.
The event which communicates the <fen>Information</fen>.
The Topic about which the Source has accurate information.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Information</fen> or the <fen>Source</fen> is correct.
The <fen>Process</fen> which is halting.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
This Frame Element marks constituents expressing the entity that is judged to be more or less suitable for some <fen>Purpose</fen> or <fen>User</fen>.
This Frame Element marks constituents that express the <fen>Purpose</fen> for which the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged to be suitable or unsuitable.
This role marks expressions that indicate a <fen>User</fen> to whom
listRoleExamples: <fex>The mailman</fex> is very exact about addresses -- he has to be .
For this they would need a thermometer accurate <fex>to within a microkelvin</fex>.
<fex>You</fex> were smart to save all your receipts.
Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
Being a project leader is not a job for which <fex>everybody</fex> is suited.
We need to plan more buildings suitable <fex>for disabled people</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: around three and a half minutes
